American Publishers Award for Professional and Scholarly Excellence (the [[PROSE Awards]]) (2012). | repec_prefix = e | repec_id = pba28 | signature = }} '''William Arnold Barnett''' (born October 30, 1941) is an [[United States|American]] [[economist]], whose current work is in the fields of [[chaos theory|chaos]], [[Bifurcation theory|bifurcation]], and [[nonlinear dynamics]] in socioeconomic contexts, [[econometric]] modeling of consumption and production, and the study of the [[aggregation problem]] and the challenges of [[measurement in economics]]. ==Education== Barnett received his B.S. degree from [[M.I.T.]], his [[M.B.A.]] from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], and his M.A. and [[Ph.D.]] from [[Carnegie Mellon University]]. ==Positions== Barnett is currently the Oswald Distinguished Professor of [[Macroeconomics]] at the [[University of Kansas]] and Director of the [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org/amfm.php Center for Financial Stability], in New York City. He is also a Senior Research Fellow of the [http://www.ic2.org/ IC2 Institute] at the University of Texas at Austin and a Fellow of the [http://krieger.jhu.edu/iae/index.html Johns Hopkins Institute for Applied Economics, Global Health, and the Study of Business Enterprise]. He is the founder and President of the [[Society for Economic Measurement]]. He was previously Research Economist at the Board of Governors of the [[Federal Reserve]] System in [[Washington, D.C.]]; Stuart Centennial Professor of Economics at the [[University of Texas]] at [[Austin]]; and Professor of Economics at [[Washington University]] in [[St. Louis]]. Prior to becoming an economist, he worked as an engineer at [[Rocketdyne]] on development of the [[Rocketdyne F-1]] rocket engine. ==Research== His research is in [[macroeconomics]] and [[econometrics]]. He is Founding President of the [[Society for Economic Measurement (SEM)|Society for Economic Measurement]], Founding Editor of the [[Cambridge University Press]] journal, [[Macroeconomic Dynamics]] and of the [[Emerald Group Publishing]] monograph series, ''[http://books.emeraldinsight.com/results.asp?sf1=series&st1=International%20Symposia%20in%20Economic%20Theory%20&%20Econometrics&sort=sort_date/d&CUR=GBP International Symposia in Economic Theory and Econometrics]'', and originator of the [[Divisia monetary aggregates]] and the "Barnett critique".{{Cite journal|url = http://research.stlouisfed.org/publications/review/article/3129|title = Empirical Evidence on the Recent Behavior and Usefulness of Simple-Sum and Weighted Measures of the Money Stock|last = Chrystal|first = Alec|date = 1994|journal = Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis Review|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = |last2 = MacDonald|first2 = Ronald|pages = 73–109}}{{Cite journal|url = http://www.nber.org/papers/w17885.pdf|title = The Barnett Critique After Three Decades: A New Keynesian Analysis|last = Belongia|first = Michael|date = 2012|journal = NBER Working Paper|accessdate = 2014|doi = 10.3386/w17885|pmid = |last2 = Ireland|first2 = Peter}} In consumer demand and production modelling, he originated the [[Laurent series]] approach to specification design and the [[seminonparametric]] approach using the [[Müntz–Szász theorem]]. His publications on bifurcation analysis and nonlinear dynamics have shown that robustness of dynamical inferences is compromised, when policy simulations are run only at point estimates of parameters, since confidence regions about those estimates are often crossed by bifurcation boundaries. He is a Fellow of the [[American Statistical Association]], a Charter Fellow of the [[Journal of Econometrics]], a Charter Fellow of the [[Society for Economic Measurement (SEM)|Society for Economic Measurement]], a Fellow of the [http://www.thewif.org.uk/ World Innovation Foundation], a Fellow of the [http://www.ic2.org/ IC2 Institute], and a Fellow of the [http://krieger.jhu.edu/iae/index.html Johns Hopkins Institute for Applied Economics, Global Health, and the Study of Business Enterprise], and Honorary Professor at [[Henan University]] in Kaifeng, China. He is ranked among the top 2% of the world's economists in [[RePEc]]. His book with Nobel Laureate, [[Paul A. Samuelson]], ''[http://www.item-book.org/ Inside the Economist's Mind: Conversations with Eminent Economists]'', [[Wiley-Blackwell]] Publishing (2007), ISBN 1-4051-5917-0, has been translated into seven languages. His ''MIT Press book'', [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org/getting_wrong.php ''Getting It Wrong: How Faulty Monetary Statistics Undermine the Fed, the Financial System, and the Economy''], ISBN 9780262516884, won the American Publishers Award for Professional and Scholarly Excellence (the [[PROSE Awards]]) for the best book published in economics during 2012. ==Honorary Journal Special Issues== Special issues of two eminent professional journals, the ''Journal of Econometrics'' and ''Econometric Reviews'', have been published in Professor Barnett's honor with contribution by many of the world's most prominent economists. These journals are: * Special issue of the [[Journal of Econometrics]] on the topic of "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/03044076/183/1 Internally Consistent Modeling, Aggregation, Inference, and Policy]," coedited in honor of William A. Barnett by [[James Heckman]] and [[Apostolos Serletis]], v. 183, no. 1, November 2014, pp. 1 - 146. * Special issue of [[Econometric Reviews]] on the topic of "[http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/lecr20/34/1-2#.VE-m01cnnyA Econometrics with Theory: A Volume Honoring William A. Barnett]," coedited by [[James Heckman]] and [[Apostolos Serletis]], v. 34, no. 1-2, 2015, pp. 1 - 254. ==Publications== ===Selected books=== * {{cite book |author=Barnett, William and Apostolos Serletis|title=[http://www.amazon.com/Monetary-Aggregation-Contributions-Economic-Analysis/dp/0444501193 The Theory of Monetary Aggregation]|publisher=Elsevier |year=2000}} * {{cite book |author=Barnett, William and Jane Binner|title=[http://www.amazon.com/Functional-Structure-Approximation-Econometrics-Contributions/dp/0444508619 Functional Structure and Approximation in Econometrics] |publisher=Elsevier |year=2004}} * {{cite book |author=Barnett, William and Paul Samuelson|title=[http://www.amazon.com/Inside-Economists-Mind-Conversations-Eminent/dp/1405159170 Inside the Economist's Mind: Conversations with Eminent Economists]|publisher=Wiley/Blackwell|year=2007}} * {{cite book |author=Barnett, William and Marcelle Chauvet|title=[http://www.amazon.com/Financial-Aggregation-Theories-Economics-Administration/dp/9814293091 Financial Aggregation and Index Number Theory]|publisher=World Scientific Publishing|year=2011}} * {{cite book |author=Barnett, William|title=[http://www.amazon.com/Getting-Wrong-Statistics-Undermine-Financial/dp/0262516888 Getting It Wrong: How Faulty Monetary Statistics Undermine the Fed, the Financial System, and the Economy]|publisher=MIT Press|year=2012}} ===Selected journal articles=== * {{cite journal |author=Barnett, William|title=Economic Monetary Aggregates: An Application of Index Number and Aggregation Theory |journal=Journal of Econometrics|date=September 1980 }} * {{cite journal |author=Barnett, William, Paul Spindt, and Edward Offenbacher|title=The New Divisia Monetary Aggregates |journal=Journal of Political Economy|date=December 1984 | doi = 10.1086/261275}} * {{cite journal |author=Barnett, William, A. R. Gallant, M. J. Hinich. J. A. Jungeilges, D. T. Kaplan, and M. J. Jensen|title=A Single-Blind Controlled Competition among Tests for Nonlinearity and Chaos |journal=Journal of Econometrics|year=1997}} * {{cite journal |author=Barnett, William, and Shu Wu|title=On User Costs of Risky Monetary Assets |journal=Annals of Finance|date=January 2005 }} * {{cite journal |author=Barnett, William|title=Multilateral Aggregation-Theoretic Monetary Aggregation over Heterogeneous Countries |journal=Journal of Econometrics|date=February 2007 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://econ.tepper.cmu.edu/barnett/Papers.html Barnett papers] * [http://alum.mit.edu/www/barnett Personal web site] * [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org Center for Financial Stability] * [http://server1.tepper.cmu.edu/barnett/SEM/default.html Society for Economic Measurement] * [http://economistmind.blogspot.com Blog] {{Neoclassical economists}} {{macroeconomics-footer}} {{History of economic thought}} {{Authority control}} {{Persondata | NAME =Barnett, William A. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =American economist | DATE OF BIRTH =October 30, 1941 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Boston, Massachusetts]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barnett, William A.}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:Tepper School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Haas School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University alumni]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:University of Kansas faculty]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:21st-century economists]] [[Category:Neoclassical economists]] [[Category:Monetary economists]]
